item.title: Introduction to OSINT
item.description:

item.content:
The Internet has become the largest repository of data in the history of humankind! If one knows how to find, identify, and use this data, it can be invaluable to forensic investigations, the reconnaissance phase of hacking, and predicting critical events.

“Ninety percent of intelligence comes from open sources. The other ten percent, the clandestine work, is just the more dramatic. The real intelligence hero is Sherlock Holmes, not James Bond.” Lt. General Samuel V. Wilson

What is OSINT?

OSINT or Open Source Intelligence - can simply be defined as Intelligence / Information gathered from publicly available resources / sources

Sources of OSINT

Open Source Intelligence comes from publicly accessible sources — both online and offline.

  1. Media
  • News outlets, TV, and online magazines.
  1. Internet & Web
  • Websites, forums, blogs, and archived data.
  1. Social Media
  • Twitter (X), LinkedIn, Reddit, Instagram.
  1. Government Data
  • Public records, registries, FOIA releases.
  1. Technical
  • DNS, WHOIS, Shodan, Censys.
  1. Academic
  • Google Scholar, arXiv.
  1. Geospatial
  • Google Maps, Sentinel Hub, OpenStreetMap.
  1. Dark Web
  • Onion sites, leak forums, Ahmia search.

OSINT is about connecting these pieces into actionable intelligence

Why It Matters

In a world driven by data, OSINT allows professionals to:

  • Discover digital footprints
  • Investigate threat actors
  • Verify information authenticity
  • Understand behavioral patterns online

Common OSINT Tools Include

Here are a few great tools to start exploring:

  • Maltego – visual link analysis tool
  • theHarvester – email and subdomain gathering
  • Shodan – search engine for Internet-connected devices
  • SpiderFoot – automation tool for OSINT collection

The OSINT FRAMEWORK

  • The OSINT Framework provides an organized collection of tools to carry out open-source Intelligence Gathering by different categories in a tree like structure

starting from the root which in this case is the overall set of OSINT branching to collective subsets all the way to a collection of tools of a particular set in the collection e.g usersearch.org for usernames , Exiftool for metadata , Cyberchef for Encoding/Decoding etc

Below is the OSINT FRAMEWORK

Google Hacking / Google Dorking

  • can be defined as a technique that uses advanced search operators in Google (or other search engines) to find information that is not easily accessible through standard, everyday search queries.

Essentially it’s about asking Google very specific, technical questions to reveal publicly indexed data that a website owner may have unintentionally exposed

How Does it Work? It leverages special keywords, symbols, and commands (called Google Dorks or Search Operators) to filter search results and pinpoint specific types of data, pages, or files.

Examples of Google Dorks include :

site :

  • Restricts the search to a specific website or domain. e.g site:nasa.gov filetype:pdf

filetype:

  • Filters results to a specific file extension. e.g filetype:log intext:password

    inurl: -Searches for specific text within a page’s URL. e.g inurl:admin login

intitle: -Finds pages with a specific word in the page title. e.g intitle:“index of” “database” Pages with “index of” and “database” in the title, often revealing open directories.

intext: -Finds pages with specific text in the body of the page.
e.g intext:“private key” Pages containing the exact phrase “private key”.
